urn:contentItem:5Y6G-S401-JDJN-63M2-00000-00GitHub launches Indian subsidiary as local developer community grows 22%2020-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisGitHub launches Indian subsidiary as local developer community grows 22%

GitHub has launched an Indian subsidiary as it looks to capitalize on recent growth in the country.

The code-hosting platform, which was acquired by Microsoft for $7.5 billion in 2018, said India is home to its third-largest community of developers and has seen 22% growth in the past year, with a 75% increase in public repositories.

Todays announcement comes nearly a year after GitHub CEO Nat Friedman revealed that the company would be making major investments in India and would build a local office from the ground up.

With its new subsidiary, called GitHub India Private Limited, both GitHub and Microsoft will be positioned to broaden their appeal to developers across the country. This also fits into a broader trend of tech giants, including Facebook and Google, going all-in to target the next billion internet users. On the flip side, India has also been introducing sweeping changes in terms of how foreign companies operate in the country, including the handling and storage of user data and other big tech regulatory oversight.

Ultimately, having a local Indian business makes a great deal of sense for any company looking to capitalize on what could prove a lucrative market.

As the third-largest group of active developers on GitHub, Indian developers are truly building the future of software, said GitHub chief operating officer Erica Brescia in a blog post. In building out a local team in India, our goal is to create stronger relationships with developers and support open source development across developers, maintainers, and enterprises.

Spearheading the new unit will be general manager Maneesh Sharma, who previously held roles at Adobe and SAP. And in the coming months, the hub will fill positions across engineering, community, sales and marketing, and more.

Its also worth noting that India is already home to several big tech companies overseas engineering offices, due in part to the growing number of developers in the country. Indeed, Uber launched an engineering center in Bengaluru back in 2016, and a report from last year indicated that the company was preparing to make India its main developer hub outside of San Francisco, with plans to increase its technical staff in the country from around 600 to 1,000 in 2020.

India is also home to one of the largest communities of student developers in the world, Brescia continued. Investing in the future of open source by empowering students is key to our efforts to support the amazing developer ecosystem in India.

As part of the launch, Brescia said GitHub Education is expanding its grant program to students across the country, promising awards of up to $1,000 for hackathon events.

Were passionate about supporting the next generation of developers, and were eager to help more student communities come together to learn and build on GitHub, Brescia added.

Meanwhile, reports emerged last month that GitHub was looking to launch a subsidiary in China. 2020 Global Data Point.

urn:contentItem:5VMJ-MR41-DYTY-C325-00000-00Give consumers control over data to curb 'Big Tech', says Treasury review;Philip Hammond expected to adopt review recommendations in today's Spring Statement2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1Give consumers control over data to curb 'Big Tech', says Treasury reviewPhilip Hammond expected to adopt review recommendations in today's Spring StatementChristopher Williams; Tim Wallace

BRITONS should be handed more control over their online data in order to break the stranglehold that tech giants have on the digital economy, according to a landmark review for the Government.

A panel of experts told the Treasury that giving consumers the ability to move their data from one digital service to another more easily would help curb the dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft in "winner-takes-most" markets.

Under proposed new rules, social network users could, for instance, shift their lists of friends, photo archives and message histories off Facebook or LinkedIn and on to a new challenger. Oversight by a "digital markets unit" could also ensure that users of messaging apps such as Facebook's Whatsapp and Apple's iMessage are able to connect with each other.

Professor Jason Furman of Harvard University, who was appointed by the Chancellor, Philip Hammond, to chair the review, said it was "better late than never" to address barriers to competition online.

Tech giants should cooperate with the Government to agree a code of conduct that can be adopted internationally and avoid tougher sanctions including a break-up, he said.

"I don't think it is too late but the sooner we get started on something like this, the better," Prof Furman said. "There is not sufficient competition today.

"This [code of conduct] is an enforceable process where you can be fined if you're not agreeing with it.

This could give a set of powerful tools. In the backdrop there is always the threat of big, cumbersome, costly antitrust cases.

"I think there are a lot of companies that want predictability. This is a route [to] predictability in a way that is less cumbersome than some."

More data portability and competi-tion from new players could mean that consumers will one day be paid to provide their personal data, Prof Furman suggested.

The Chancellor said last night: "We know some tech giants are still accumulating too much power, preventing smaller businesses from entering the market." Mr Hammond added that he will set out plans to implement the review's recommendations.

Speaking as the web turned 30 years old, Prof Furman rejected claims by tech industry lobbyists that competition is only ever a click away in digital markets and that today's giants could one day fall victim to innovative upstarts.

"I think 15 years ago you could think that even if there is one dominant platform at a point in time, who knows how long that platform will last? In the early days of the internet you went through Yahoo, Lycos, Altavista, on your way to Google. But now it has been a while." The review echoed calls by last month's Cairncross review of the funding of journalism for the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to launch a formal study of the "opaque" digital advertising market, which is dominated by Google and Facebook. The CMA said last night that it was considering such a move but that its "ability to launch new projects is heavily dependent on the outcome of EU exit negotiations". Prof Furman also suggested that the CMA's approach to tech mergers "needs a reset" and that watchdogs should be backed by new legislation to take "firmer and more frequent" action to challenge takeovers that could harm competition and innovation in the future.

Scrutiny of mergers between companies that do not directly compete should also be tightened, the review said, and past takeovers should be revisited. Facebook's takeovers of Instagram and Whatsapp, Google's acquisitions of YouTube and the advertising network Doubleclick were all waved through but are now seen in the digital sector as crucial steps towards their dominance.

Prof Furman said that under his proposals it was "very plausible" that some big tech mergers would have been blocked by the CMA "but the large majority wouldn't have been".

The report, which the Government is due to consider and formally respond to in summer, is Britain's latest contribution to a global debate on how to harness the power of the web.

In Australia yesterday, Rupert Murdoch's News Corp urged regulators to break up Google and its "overwhelming" power. In the US the Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren has pledged to attack Facebook over alleged abuses of personal data.

Prof Furman said moves to break up tech giants were premature, however, and that it should be possible to preserve the convenience of the big players while opening them up to new rivals.

"We're not recommending that and it is not the place I would start," he said. "If you adopted all these recommendations, you'd get all the benefits you get from being on a platform, while taking away some of the harms and abuses those platforms could undertake, and also enabling new entrants.

"This is a really robust proposal - I would rather go this route at least for now because it preserves the benefits while constraining the harms, as opposed to something I think would be more uncertain and potentially risky."

urn:contentItem:5Y5B-KTY1-JC8Y-81VJ-00000-00Give Me a Crash Course In . . . Tinder privacy2020-02-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisWEEKENDPg. 8Give Me a Crash Course In . . . Tinder privacyEoin Butler

What happened this week? The Data Protection Commissioner (DPC) announced it was investigating matchmaking site Tinder over alleged failings in how they treat their user data.

So, a big tech company might not have looked after my data? I am shocked. You big cynic. But yes, Tinder could be in hot water with Ireland's DPC, which gets to regulate the dating site by virtue of the fact that it has a small corporate establishment here (MTCH Technology Services Ltd), which, it turns out, is actually its legal headquarters for all of Europe. It has only two employees and sustained a loss of $19,000 last year, but it's the legal residency that counts. Alongside Tinder, MTCH is the parent company for lots of other matchmaking services such as OkCupid, Plenty of Fish and Match.

What are they supposed to have done? The official notice of the investigation is quite vague. It refers to "a number of issues" identified by individuals in Ireland and the EU relating to the processing of users' personal data, processing activities on the Tinder platform, as well as transparency surrounding ongoing processing.

Clear as mud. I sense it's something to do with processing? You'll go far. Processing is an important term in the realm of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the strict EU rules on data privacy that came into force in 2018.

Those rules oblige companies that process your data - which means collecting, storing, distributing or destroying data, among other things. Basically, if you interact with user data, you're processing it, and that brings lots of responsibilities.

Tinder is also being investigated over how it complies with data subject rights requests. This is when a user asks a company for all the data it holds on them - they're supposed to comply and share it all with you. This is where things get a bit more interesting.

Why so? Well, helpfully, one of the complainants has posted some correspondence between the DPC and Tinder online. We only have one side of what effectively is a three-way conversation, but it does reveal part of what he was looking for and couldn't get out of the company, as well as what kind of information Tinder does store on its users.

Ooh. I'd swipe right on that info! Geddit? Very funny. Actually, it seems the company does store information about your swipes. The correspondence posted online shows what information the app gathers on its users, and it's quite extensive. An non-exhaustive list include basic info like name, birthday, education status and email address, but also travel and location data, interests, identification information about users' phones, profile pictures, the songs you listen to, data on your "swipes", matches, sent messages and information about any purchases you have made on the platform. The user in question also didn't get a lot of information they had requested, including messages they had received on the platform.

Why not? Tinder argues that it isn't obliged to release data like that, because it impinges on the other party in the conversation's reasonable expectation of privacy. And that's just some of the information held - it's understood the investigation is looking at whether what is released to users matches the data that its privacy policy suggests is collected.

Overall, the story shows just how much data is being gathered by these companies about the people who use their platforms. Especially when it's something as sensitive as your love life, you'd be well advised to live by the motto: "If you wouldn't wear it on a T-shirt, don't post it on the internet."

urn:contentItem:5Y09-XYK1-JBHT-D01Y-00000-00Give me Dom Perignon and Louis Vuitton, or give me death!2020-01-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisOPINIONGive me Dom Perignon and Louis Vuitton, or give me death!Tiana LoweWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

President Trump has been right to stand up against censorious and sinophilic technology conglomerates. But his administration seems wrongly keen on punishing us ordinary folks as part of his war to protect American Big Tech.

In retaliation to France's 3% digital services tax, the Trump administration is poised to impose tariffs of up to 100% on French wine, handbags, and cheeses.

To punish France, Trump may just double the price of your evening Bordeaux. We started a revolution over much less.

Trump's trade war has confounded economists for many reasons, none more than its bevy of contradictions. Trump has correctly pushed the Overton window on China's regime to make the planet come to terms with the nation's undeniable threat to the Western world. Yet he continues to isolate and aggravate our democratic allies when that's the last thing he should be doing. In this case, Trump isn't just punishing a crucial ally in our struggle against China. He's doing so to protect the multinational tech conglomerates that, in every other context, he loathes more than almost anything.

The French digital services tax, however ill-advised it is in principle, will only apply to some 30 tech giants. Those include Amazon, Google, Facebook, and Apple. Why would Trump want to punish his own people to protect companies he despises?TweetTweetTweetTweet

It's easy to write off the woes of the French billionaires who own Balenciaga and Veuve Cliquot, but Trump's tariffs could decimate our $70 billion wine industry. Imports comprise one-third of our domestic market, which employs nearly a million Americans directly and over 1.7 million indirectly. Anywhere between 10,000 and 17,000 Americans could lose their jobs if Trump actually did tariff French wine at 100%, and even more would lose their jobs across the food services and luxury goods industries.

We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, have until midnight to give the federal government a piece of our minds. Head over to regulations.gov to stick it to a big government that insists on taxing and surveilling you while depriving you of a reasonably priced wheel of Camembert at the same time. Give us Dior, or give us death!

urn:contentItem:5Y3N-BC61-F021-60YR-00000-00Given a chance, Big Tech could stop the next deadly pandemic2020-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Given a chance, Big Tech could stop the next deadly pandemicBy Garry White

It is important a desire for privacy in the West does not stop firms innovating for the common good

China's authoritarianism should be an asset in its fight against coronavirus, as controlling the spread of a disease is much easier in a surveillance state.

As well as tracking an individual's movements, data highlighting clusters of disease can be used by medical professionals to target resources effectively. Big Data could help stop a global pandemic in its tracks - but Western concerns about privacy mean major tech players may be hamstrung by regulators.

As governments, particularly those in Europe, push for tighter regulations on Big Tech, it's important that our individual desire for privacy does not stop these companies from innovating for the common good. As we leave the European Union, the Government needs to remember that bad regulation stifles creativity.

Privacy is important, but innovation is too. This is therefore one area that we need to see divergence from Brussels.

Regulation is the biggest current threat to the technology sector. New governance rules come with a cost and will inevitably hit company margins - and valuations - in one of the most important drivers of market returns.

This week, Facebook shares tumbled after the company posted its weakest rate of growth since going public. David Wehner, its chief financial officer, noted that global privacy regulation was going to increasingly hit growth.

"Though we have experienced some modest impact from these headwinds to date, the majority of the impact lies in front of us," Wehner said. It is likely that Google-owner Alphabet will make similar statements when it posts numbers on Monday.

There are not only moves to increase taxation on these companies, but rules to further limit what they can do with the information they collect on individuals is likely. However, scrutinising big sets of data can produce useful outcomes for us all - and could help effectively control the spread of diseases such as coronavirus.

Data from mobile phone towers can be used to track users who have been close to a known case of a virus. Facial recognition tech can track individuals - although it fails when people wear face masks, as Beijing has discovered in Hong Kong.

Databases can be used to enter patients' details at medical facilities, providing a clear picture of the outbreak itself. This is just a fraction of the benefits of Big Data.

As a surveillance state, China should have been in an ideal position to nip the outbreak in the bud. Beijing defends the monitoring of its citizens as a way of keeping them "safe", but its initial reactions may have done the opposite.

The current outbreak coincided with China's Golden Week holiday, where millions of people travel around the country to see family and loved ones. In a huge state such as China, these movements make it very difficult to control the spread of a disease. But it now appears that measures to stop its spread could have been introduced last year.

It emerged this week that the first case of coronavirus in Wuhan started showing symptoms on Dec 1. As alarm grew in medical circles it appears the Communist Party tried to prevent them expressing their fears.

A doctor who told a social media group about the virus was reportedly disciplined and forced to admit wrongdoing. It was also noted that the police provided "education" and "criticism" to eight doctors for "rumour-mongering" about the epidemic. The initial, instinctive response from Beijing now appears to be a cover up. This is likely to have led to the virus spreading - and has even prompted rare criticism of president Xi Jinping by Chinese citizens.

Scrutinising data sets to boost public health has already demonstrated success. In the UK, the NHS has been sharing data with Google unit DeepMind, to some criticism and disquiet amongst privacy campaigners.

However, as we know with vaccination programmes, public health is always a balance between the greater good and an individual's rights. If properly regulated, allowing tech majors to build and scrutinise large series of data sets could be very useful indeed.

DeepMind's latest success with NHS data relates to the detecting of breast cancer, with early research suggesting its algorithm can improve the accuracy of mammogram screenings - reducing false negatives.

Not only will over-regulating the technology sector hand a potential advantage to the Chinese - where no such privacy concerns exit - it could prevent new technologies being developed.

The new European Commission, under president Ursula von der Leyen, is targeting what it sees as problems with the digital economy. It wants to modernise competition law to prevent large, power players becoming dominant, and set a robust framework for the use of artificial intelligence and algorithms.

In a post-Brexit UK, technology could become an important driver of growth as the country establishes its new identity. Sajid Javid, the Chancellor, recently made it clear that Britain will diverge from European Union rules after Brexit, although he did not specify which ones.

It is clear that technology regulation is one area in that we need to diverge, becoming closer to the looser, libertarian model of the US than the highly regulated and controlled market envisioned by Brussels. Such a move will not only be good for our economy - it will probably be good for our health too.

Garry White is chief investment commentator at Charles Stanley

urn:contentItem:5SSB-Y721-JCJY-G0FY-00000-00Given Facebook's puny fine, it's no surprise Mark Zuckerberg has snubbed MPs2018-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1Given Facebook's puny fine, it's no surprise Mark Zuckerberg has snubbed MPsBy James Titcomb

Four months after Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal erupted, the company has been handed its first financial penalty over the fiasco.

On Wednesday, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) proposed a £500,000 fine for the social media giant . The sum is a record penalty imposed by the UK's data watchdog, but by Facebook's standards, it was chump change.

For its role in a controversy that covers multiple elections and saw the details of millions of Facebook users compromised, the world's fifth biggest company, run by the world's fourth-richest man, faces a fine equal to the price of a one-bed flat in Zone 2.

Facebook's revenue last year totalled $40.7bn (£30.7bn), so half a million pounds takes just under 10 minutes to make back. Facebook spent twice that much on private planes for Mark Zuckerberg last year .

Cushioning the blow further, Facebook's fine could well end up being reduced, if the company challenges it, or elects to pay early.

Facebook | Revenues in dollars

The paucity of the penalty is not down to reluctance on the part of the ICO. The regulator's hands were tied by the 1998 Data Protection Act, a law that pre-dates Facebook by six years. Its devisers never anticipated the scale of data controversies that would erupt in the next century.

GDPR, the new European law that supersedes the act, came into force in May. Under it, Facebook would have faced a maximum fine of $1.6bn, 4pc of last year's revenue. However, the loophole that exposed 87m users' private details to be unwittingly collected and passed to Cambridge Analytica was closed in 2015.

Elizabeth Denham, the Information Commissioner, admitted as much on Wednesday when she suggested that under the new laws, the company could have been fined hundreds of millions.

She claimed the reputational damage of being fined was more significant. That is hard to believe. There is no evidence that Facebook's users have fled the social network; many who tweeted #deletefacebook in the aftermath of the controversy are likely to have returned. The company's share price is   at an all-time high, and no significant advertisers have abandoned it.

It is little surprise, therefore, that the company has answered questions from MPs with what have been described as a "consistently slow and unsatisfactory responses" . Despite repeated requests and the threat of a formal summons, Zuckerberg himself as refused to give evidence, much to the chagrin of the Commons committee investigating the case.

Facebook has instead largely devoted time to where it faces serious sanctions: Washington, where a phalanx of agencies including the FBI are investigating it; and Brussels, the centre of power most hostile to big tech.

Belatedly, the UK authorities now have the teeth to introduce appropriate sanctions when companies fail to care for private information. Next time, perhaps, that will mean something.

urn:contentItem:60Y3-TGV1-JBNF-W1JY-00000-00Give up Google, don't hit 'accept all': how to fight for your privacy2020-09-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisBOOKSVersion:1Give up Google, don't hit 'accept all': how to fight for your privacyElle Hunt

In Privacy Is Power, professor Carissa Véliz has made a shocking survey of how much intimate data we are surrendering. But she has a plan to fight back

"If you're reading this book, you probably already know your personal data is being collected, stored and analysed," Carissa Véliz begins, in Privacy Is Power. Her challenge, as a writer and a privacy advocate, is to shake us out of our complacency; to persuade us to see this not as a necessary sacrifice in the digital age, but an intolerable invasion. From the mounting dread I felt while reading Privacy Is Power, I'd say she was successful.

From the moment you wake up and first check your phone, to the marketers that infer your mood from your music choices, to the smart speaker that shares your private conversations, or the television that listens in on them (from the terms and conditions of a Samsung smart TV: "Please be aware that if your spoken words include personal or other sensitive information, that information will be among the data captured"), there is nowhere to hide - or even just be - in this hyper-connected hellscape. Corporations can track you both by your face and your digital footprint, your medical records may be handed over to Big Tech, and advertisers may learn of your break-up before you do. In her book, Véliz, a professor at the Institute for Ethics in AI at Oxford University, often veers into the second person, cleverly underscoring her point: it's impossible not to picture yourself blindly navigating this horror, then you remember - you already are.

Your data may already be being used against you, says Véliz, with far-reaching implications for trust, equality, justice and democracy. "It doesn't matter if you think you don't need privacy," she says. "Your society needs you to have privacy."

Véliz's introduction to the issue was deeply personal. In 2013, while researching her family history, she uncovered some surprising details about her late grandfather that she could only assume he had not wanted her to find out. "I started wondering whether I had a right to know all these things that my grandparents didn't tell me." That same summer, Edward Snowden made history by telling the world about mass surveillance at the NSA. "It was a very personal thing in the beginning," says Véliz, "then I became very worried about our society, and it became a professional interest."

In Japan last year, a man sexually assaulted a pop star, claiming he had found her by analysing reflections in her eyes in photos she had posted online

Privacy Is Power is a slim book on a vast, complex issue, made more powerful by Véliz accepting her limits. ("Facebook has violated our right to privacy so many times that a comprehensive account would merit a book in itself," she writes.) It is highly readable, clearly laying out a problem that many of us have lost sight of. "When companies collect your data, it doesn't hurt, you don't feel the absence, you don't see it physically," Véliz says. "We're having to learn as we have bad experiences."

She writes of a Spanish woman, a victim of identity theft, who has spent years being pulled in and out of police stations and courtrooms for crimes committed in her name. "My life has been ruined," the woman says, just one among nearly 225,000 such cases recorded in the UK last year alone. Last month, a Detroit man was wrongly arrested on the basis of a facial recognition algorithm. ("I guess the computer got it wrong," one detective reportedly said.) In Japan last year, a man sexually assaulted a pop star, claiming he had identified her location by analysing reflections in her eyes in photos she had posted online. And Véliz describes a data scientist-in-training being tasked with investigating a stranger, simply for the exercise of it: "He ended up studying in depth some guy in Virginia who, he learned, had diabetes and was having an affair."

The problem is hard to manage even within our civic institutions, who look to tech as the answer to everything, even when it is not fully understood (the exam results fiasco being a recent example). "When somebody says AI is 'cutting edge', many times what they are saying is, 'We haven't tested it enough to know if it works,'" says Véliz. "It shouldn't be tested on an entire population without our knowledge, consent or compensation ... We're being treated as guinea pigs."

Privacy is Power is out just as the UK government has launched its new contact-tracing app. Véliz says there is little to suggest it will be effective - and certainly not without accompanying mass testing - because by the time people are alerted that they have come into contact with a confirmed case, they will have already infected others.

"The first app was a complete fiasco, and everybody knew it was going to be," says Véliz. Whether the second is an improvement remains to be seen, but privacy and security risks are a certainty. Imperial College researchers estimate that trackers installed on the phones of just 1% of London's population could account for the real-time location of more than half the city.

As history has shown, it is easier for governments to erode civil liberties at times of social upheaval, and many can't be trusted with the information they collect; just this month, 18,000 people had personal information published online by mistake by Public Health Wales. "It's very expensive to get tech right and most governments don't have the money or expertise... we're giving very sensitive data to institutions that are not capable of keeping it safe," says Véliz. "We seem to be not ready for this kind of power."

But misuse of our data is not the only threat to our privacy. Cooperation between public bodies and corporations - such as the border control contract awarded to Palantir, the tech firm assisting the Trump administration to deport migrants from the US; or the UK police's support of Uber receiving a licence in exchange for its data - should be ongoing cause for concern. "It's a public institution giving support to tech that might, on the whole, be detrimental to society," says Véliz.

A tech specialist might have been tempted to focus on the whys and hows of our structural surveillance, in doing so (even inadvertently) affirming the need for it. Framed by a philosopher as an ethical question, it is obviously intolerable. "This isn't publicity: this keeps me up at night," she says.

Still, Véliz is adamant that there is reason to be hopeful. "People didn't think the GDPR was going to be possible, they thought privacy was dead, it was a thing of the past - and obviously it's not. I am very optimistic that this level of intrusion is not sustainable." What she wants is for more people to exercise their agency over how their data is used, both to protect themselves and to send a bigger statement. Even the biggest tech companies depend on people's cooperation, she points out: "If we look for privacy-friendly alternatives, they will thrive."

She sets out practical steps for taking back control, such as swapping Google for privacy-friendly search engines such as DuckDuckGo, taping over your webcam when it is not in use, asking people for permission before posting about them online, using password managers and VPNs to obscure your IP address, and choosing "dumb" devices over "smart" ones. (Privacy Is Power has convinced me that Amazon Alexa offers no benefit sufficient to justify its sinister presence. Check the forecast yourself.)

"It's a hard thing to do if you do everything, and if you do it perfectly - but you don't have to do either to make a big difference," says Véliz. Though regulation remains needed, it is refreshing to see practical solutions for a situation it is hard to not feel powerless about - as well as a reminder that this will continue unless we make it clear it's unacceptable.

"We should be outraged. Companies are very worried about what people think. If people tweet about this, talk about it, choose better products, things can turn around in a matter of very few years," Véliz says. Disingenuous it may be, but a recent Apple ad trumpeting the importance of privacy is proof that, at least, they know the public is concerned.

The first step towards revolution may simply be becoming more aware of how freely you hand over your data, and to whom. Did you need to click "yes" to that cookies pop-up? Should you tell all of Twitter where you are? Does your fridge really need to be connected to the internet? When asked for her email address, Véliz will often give noneofyourbusiness@privacy.com, "to make a point".

Privacy Is Power: Why and How You Should Take Back Control of Your Data, by Carissa Véliz is published by Bantam Press. To order a copy, go to guardianbookshop.com.

urn:contentItem:5S05-MD11-JCJY-G46C-00000-00GKN shareholders vote on £8.1bn Melrose bid - latest news as biggest hostile takeover battle in a decade comes to conclusion2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1GKN shareholders vote on £8.1bn Melrose bid - latest news as biggest hostile takeover battle in a decade comes to conclusionBy Tom Rees

GKN shareholders have until 1pm to back Melrose's £8.1bn hostile bid

Shareholder vote in bitter battle expected to go down to the wire; decision by 5pm

Which way should GKN shareholders vote as Melrose takeover battle comes to a head?

GKN versus Melrose: How Britain's biggest corporate takeover battle for a decade unfolded

FTSE 100 nudges higher ahead of Easter break

UK economy slowed in 2017 but less than initially thought

GDP growth last year nudged down to 1.8pc from 1.9pc

Renault shares surge on reports of mega merger talks with Nissan

Shire a victim of its own success as bid moves closer

 11:29AM GKN takeover battle - what the City analysts think 

We've had the view of GKN customers, trade unions and MPs on the battle for the engineering giant but what are City analysts urging shareholders to do with less than two hours to go?

Numis has told clients to back Melrose's bid to get long-term value from GKN but stick with its current management to get a quick fix.

Its analyst David Larkham explained:

"Contra to the early days rhetoric in this hostile bid process, we suggest those looking for short-term face value should vote for the GKN management plan and Dana transaction; those with longer-term horizons should opt for the Melrose proposal with the full potential of Driveline to be delivered."

Jefferies sits on the fence, saying that there are no "bad choices here" for shareholders and that GKN has done well to offer shareholders a credible alternative.

It said:

"We believe Melrose morphs into GKN, possibly for years. By mid-2017, we believe shareholders wanted the dissolution of GKN. Over 10 weeks, we have moved from having to choose largely on best management execution to having to choose between two different strategies because GKN did what was wanted. Not that it makes either choice the blatantly obvious."

10:48AM GKN shares climb on deadline day as hesitant FTSE 100 nudges up

Couple of comments about the possible sale of @GKN_plc to @Melroseplc for asset-stripping/break-up 1. If this was France or Germany it would be blocked immediately and without hesitation

- Christian Harris (@Chalfont14) March 29, 2018

Keeping up the fight for @GKN_plc to the last ..... @unitetheunion will never stop fighting to defend our members and the UK's national interests nor holding Govt to account for their refusal to do the same!! https://t.co/ayQd9tIhlx

- Steve Turner (@SteveT_Unite) March 28, 2018

GKN shares are nudging higher on deadline day for Melrose's hostile takeover bid with the FTSE 100 tentatively advancing ahead of the Easter break.

Volatility has eased on markets and a "volatile first half of the week appears to be giving way to a more stable and hesitant second half", according to IG's Joshua Mahony.

The drama "looks set to roll on" with Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg agreeing to testify in Congress but the "outperformance in Asia and Europe highlights the relative lack of contagion for a tech industry which is predominantly US listed", he added.

10:12AM Which way should GKN shareholders vote as Melrose takeover battle comes to a head? 

You almost wish that the UK Takeover Panel would extend the 60-day deadline for Melrose to win shareholder approval for its bid to buy GKN just for sheer entertainment value.

The hostile battle, which is due to conclude today,  has been one of the most engrossing corporate ding-dongs for many a year with both sides clearly up for a fight and more than happy to rip verbal chunks out of each other.

Read the Telegraph's verdict on the battle here

9:44AM UK economy slowed in 2017 but less than initially thought

The UK economy officially slowed down in 2017 but growth cooled less than initially thought, ONS figures have indicated this morning.

The ONS left its 0.4pc estimate for the fourth quarter of 2017 unchanged but upgraded its previous overall estimate for growth last year by 0.1 percentage point to 1.8pc, a small decline from the 1.9pc growth recorded the year before. 

The pound has barely budged on currency markets following the growth upgrade, remaining 0.4pc lower against the dollar at $1.4055.

9:26AM Renault shares surge on Nissan merger talks report

Shares in French carmaker Renault surged 7.8pc following a Bloomberg report that it is in talks to merge with Japan's Nissan to create a new company that would trade as a single stock.  

The automakers currently have a strategic partnership, formed in 1999. Renault owns 43pc of Nissan, while the Japanese company owns 15pc of Renault.

Carlos Ghosn is chairman of the joint alliance as well as chief executive of Renault, a job he will have for at least another four years. Mr Ghosn folded troubled carmaker Mitsubishi into the group in 2016.

Read Ayesha Javed's full report here

9:09AM GKN takeover battle 'the most bitter in recent memory'

D-day for Melrose/GKN today after about 10 weeks of pretty brutal back and forths between the two. Deadline is 1pm with result out before 5pm - #hostiletakeover#aerospace

- Benjamin Katz (@_benkatz) March 29, 2018

Biggest hostile takeover bid in the UK for nearly a decade has pitted one of Britain's largest industrial groups, GKN, which began as a South Wales ironworks in 1759, against a company set up in 2003(Melrose) with the aim of buying up and turning around underperforming businesses

- Devesh Vishwakarma (@deveshl) March 29, 2018

Everyone from trade unions, Government ministers and GKN customer Airbus have weighed in on the Melrose takeover bid but its shareholders will have the final say today.

It has been "the most bitter takeover battle in recent memory" and could have a "lasting impact on UK takeover rules", according to Interactive Investor's Lee Wild.

He added that a GKN victory would trigger selling in GKN shares because "Melrose backers bet that benefits take far longer to feed through than they would have done had the bidder won".

8:46AM 2,500 jobs at risk as Bargain Booze owner Conviviality heads into administration

Conviviality has become the latest retailer to collapse into administration, putting more than 2,500 jobs at risk, after failing to secure emergency funds from investors. 

Problems have been mounting for the Bargain Booze owner  over the past couple of weeks, as it revealed a string of profit warnings,  axed its chief executive  and said it was facing a £30m tax bill, which is due today.

Conviviality  last week had issued a plea to investors for £125m in cash, in a last-ditch attempt to raise enough funds to pay off the tax bill and reduce its debts.

Read Hannah Boland's full report here

8:38AM Agenda: Biggest hostile takeover battle in a decade comes to a conclusion as GKN shareholders vote on £8.1bn Melrose bid

A fierce hostile takeover battle for engineering giant GKN finally comes a conclusion today with a shareholder vote over Melrose's £8.1bn bid set to go down to the wire. 

GKN's management has thrown the kitchen sink at keeping restless shareholders on board. It has agreed a deal to merge its Driveline division with US peer Dana, pledged to increase shareholder returns and conducted a ruthless campaign questioning Melrose's suitability.

Turnaround specialist Melrose has promised to keep GKN's headquarters and listing in the UK, sought to allay national security concerns and called time on a management which has presided over a period of stagnation for the FTSE 100 firm.

Shareholders have until 1pm today to back Melrose's bid with a decision due by 5pm.

- Holger Zschaepitz (@Schuldensuehner) March 29, 2018

GKN shares are flat ahead of the decision on the FTSE 100, which has nudged higher in early trading. Tech shares came under renewed pressure in the US overnight, dragging the Dow Jones and tech-heavy NASDAQ back into the red after a brighter start. 

European equities are brushing aside the tech wobble in the US ahead of the Easter break with the DAX and CAC 40 also moving higher early on.

urn:contentItem:5VTW-R151-JB20-G2HS-00000-00Glacier Bancorp Inc Acquisition of Heritage Bancorp Conference Call - Final2019-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexis040419a12458052.752Glacier Bancorp Inc Acquisition of Heritage Bancorp Conference Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Barry L. Johnston

Glacier Bancorp, Inc. - Senior VP & Chief Credit Officer

* Randall M. Chesler

Glacier Bancorp, Inc. - President, CEO & Director

* Ronald J. Copher

Glacier Bancorp, Inc. - Executive VP, CFO & Secretary

Conference Call Participants

* Jacquelynne Chimera Bohlen

Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc., Research Division - MD, Equity Research

* Matthew Timothy Clark

Piper Jaffray Companies, Research Division - Principal & Senior Research Analyst

* Michael Masters Young

SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division - VP and Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Glacier Bancorp Investor Conference Call. (Operator Instructions) As a reminder, this call is being recorded.

I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Randy Chesler, President and CEO of Glacier Bancorp. Please go ahead, sir.

RANDALL M. CHESLER, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, GLACIER BANCORP, INC.: Great. Well, thank you, Sarah. Hi. Good morning to everyone, and thank you for joining us. I'm here in Reno, Nevada, very excited to tell you about our most recent transaction. Joining me on the phone from Kalispell is Ron Copher, our Chief Financial Officer; Don Chery, our Chief Administrative Officer; and Barry Johnston, our Chief Credit Administrator.

So last night, after the close of business, we announced our agreement to partner with Heritage Bancorp, the holding company for Heritage Bank of Nevada, a community bank based right here in Reno. They've got $830 million in assets, and Heritage is the largest bank headquartered in Northern Nevada and the largest community bank headquartered in Nevada and, probably, most importantly, one of the best-performing community banks in the United States.

This transaction, along with First National Bank of Layton, which was announced in January, will add over $1.1 billion in assets to our balance sheet in 2019. That makes 2019 one of our busiest years ever. I'm also pleased to announce that we received all the regulatory approvals for the First National Bank of Layton transaction and expect to close that at the end of April. So Nevada has been a key state in the Glacier Western footprint, and we've been very patiently waiting for the right entry point for a number of years. There are limited number of community banks in the state and a very high level of interest among a number of competitors to grow or expand into this market.

Heritage Bank is clearly the best and only choice for us to become our first division in Nevada. So I'd like to jump right into the investor presentation we sent out. Starting on Page 2, this outlines the transaction. This will be our 22nd announced transaction since 2000, our 11th in the last 6 years. Upon closing, Heritage will become our 16th bank division. The transaction, as you can see, is part cash, part stock, shareholders getting 4 shares of Glacier common stock in addition to $12 in cash. Based on the closing price last night, that puts the aggregate deal value at about $240 million, inclusive of the consideration to the Heritage option holders.

If you go through Page 3, this transaction, we believe, is very consistent with our long-held strategy of buying good banks, good markets with good people. Heritage checks all these boxes and then some. Really feel this is very low risk. Heritage is already a top-performing bank, and we're planning for very minimal cost savings and, therefore, very little risk of disruption in a market that we're very excited about. With our model, as you know, we keep the people, and we really just focus on helping our acquired banks serve their customers with expanded products and services. We feel will be very well received in this market.

If you take a look at Page 4, you can look at the operating markets that Heritage operates in. It's home market of Reno, heritage has 5 very strategic important locations with almost $600 million in deposits. Also a presence in Carson City, the state capital, Gardnerville, which is a prime tourist jumping off point for South Lake Tahoe. Nevada is one of the fastest-growing states in the country in terms of population growth. And Reno is -- as you can see, from some of the information we put in there, just a tremendous amount of things happening there. Within the MSA that Heritage operates, it's got the top share among community banks.

If you jump to Page 5, you really begin -- you can see Reno -- it's a significant and really a stunning transformation over the last decade. It's now ranked -- Reno is now ranked as one of the top places in the country to live and work. It's home to the University of Nevada, Reno that got world-class medicine, engineering and business. Engineering is key because they crank out engineers which support the big tech presence here.

This state is low-cost, very business-friendly, very favorable tax code located right next to California. So very, very positive positioning. It's become a very strong logistic shipping point for West Coast and also a very strong tech center, given its proximity to Silicon Valley. All of this is contributing to Reno becoming one of the fastest-growing cities in the country and the Heritage as the only community bank headquartered in the city. This dominant market position is very, very exciting.

If you look at Pages 6 and 7, you'll see that Heritage is one of the highest-performing banks in the country, and that's not just something recent. They've been performing at this level for a number of years, and that is very important to us. They're a very efficient operator with very strong net interest margin, a great deposit base and absolutely pristine asset quality that has been proven through multiple economic cycles. You can see that on Page 7. For 2018, their return on assets was 2.31%, their net margin was 4.38%, and they had an efficiency ratio of 37.2%.

If you look at Pages 8 and 9 on the deck, you can see the outline of the transactions and our assumption, and which I mentioned earlier, very consistent with our historic approach on acquisitions. We're very happy with the financial metrics of this deal. Our cost savings assumptions are very conservative at 14.4%, and the transaction is immediately accretive to our earnings. The internal rate of return in excess of 15%. Minimal tangible book value dilution, it's earned back in 1.3 years.

And very importantly to us, the multiple on 2019 earnings is an extremely attractive 12.6 times. So -- 12.9 -- 12.6 times. So we really have worked a while with the Heritage folks for a number of years, talking to them. Very happy to see this come to fruition. We think it's going to be, as you can see, very accretive to our franchise, a great addition, consistent with our history of buying really good banks in good markets with good people. So we're very excited to have this exceptional bank join our team. We welcome the very talented Heritage team to our company.

And with that, those are my comments. And at this point, I'll end that and turn the call back over to Sarah to see if there's any questions.

Questions and Answers

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from the line of Jackie Bohlen with KBW.

JACQUELYNNE CHIMERA BOHLEN, MD, EQUITY RESEARCH, KEEFE, BRUYETTE, & WOODS, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: I have just a couple of questions to kick it off here. In terms of the efficiency ratio that Heritage has been able to achieve, I mean, that's absolutely fabulous. What is a big driver for them? I'm guessing it probably has something to do with the high level of deposits per branch. But I guess, what other things are they doing that enable them to achieve that level?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Yes, they're a very effective bank positioned with dominant market share in a 0.5 million person market. So you can see that in their average deposits per branch in excess of $100 million. If you look at the loans to commercial lender, it's almost 5x our average across our network. So their efficiency is both revenue and expense driven, primarily driven by very attractive deposit costs as well as some of the high amount of demand and very efficient way that they are tapping into that.

JACQUELYNNE CHIMERA BOHLEN: Okay. And in terms of their depositors, what does a typical depositor look like at the bank to the extent that there is one? What I'm trying to get at is with the high level of deposits that are per branch, is that just driven by a lot of customers or there are customers that have higher balances?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: It's pretty well spread out. There's a high -- very high connection to the lending. So there's a very significant portion of that, almost 40%, is noninterest. And so, they really have created a culture here, Stan, who really built the bank and Tom. They really demand deposits with every deal, and so they're looking for the relationship. So I would -- I'm looking at it, term it, very much a relationship-based deposit franchise. Really no big sticky, no big large chunks in there, but pretty well spread out, again, overweight on business accounts, but a pretty good consumer base as well.

JACQUELYNNE CHIMERA BOHLEN: Okay. That's helpful. Just one last one from me, and then I'll step back. Do you happen to have the exact share count that you'll be adding and then any impact that the options might have on the diluted share count?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: I am in here in Reno. Ron is back in Kalispell. And let me just check to see. Ron, do you have that number handy?

RONALD J. COPHER, EXECUTIVE VP, CFO & SECRETARY, GLACIER BANCORP, INC.: I don't have it handy, but I can call you later with that information.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Young with SunTrust.

MICHAEL MASTERS YOUNG, VP AND ANALYST, SUNTRUST ROBINSON HUMPHREY, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Congrats on the deal. Wanted to start off just on kind of the growth profile. You obviously have highlighted the strength of the markets, and I think that's pretty evident externally. But maybe just talk about kind of the opportunity sets that you see for growth in terms of both the magnitude and then maybe the areas of growth. I think they have more of a CRE focus in the past. Will that still be the focus going forward? Just some color there would be helpful.

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Sure. Well the -- yes, the growth opportunity is significant. And one of the things we do stress is we want the bank to just really just keep doing what it's doing and not take our bigger balance sheet and do things that haven't done, but serve their customers. What we've seen, though, is, as we bring our product set to the market, that, generally, there's a pretty good pickup. So for example, our municipal lending product, they really don't offer that today. Some of our tax-advantaged products, they don't really offer those today. And so, I think that larger loans -- I think that there are some customers that may have gotten a little large, that they can now serve. So very similar to the other markets that we enter. I think there's a lot of opportunity here because the market is growing and very, very healthy. But we want the bank to just continue to do their things. Our main focus is to help them do that, not lose any of their customers as we go through the transition here and continue to serve their customers, and I think some of this incremental growth will follow.

MICHAEL MASTERS YOUNG: Okay. And then any assumptions in terms of what you're expecting in terms of growth going forward for them? Would you expect it to be, for instance, a little higher pace than the rest of the bank as a whole or...?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: We didn't model that. We kept it relatively conservative just for all the reasons I just went through.

MICHAEL MASTERS YOUNG: Okay. Perfect. And then one other thing you always talk about, a good bank in a good market with good people. Can you maybe just give us a little bit of a view into the people side? They were run pretty efficiently, but any outlook on kind of the management team going forward.

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Sure. I spent a fair amount of time with Rob, the Chairman; and Stan, who is the CEO; Tom, who is Chief Credit Officer. Very, very great operators, great relationships with the customers. Just done a fantastic job establishing this bank in this market, to really be the community bank in this very, very good market. Beneath them is a very strong team I've spent some time with. They have good tenures. So I think a number of folks have been here for a number of years. Very good relationships in this -- in the Reno market. So I think those things are just what we see the branch management staff has generally been in place for a number of years. So but that's all attractive to us. That's all back to the core relationships that they're able to have established and maintained. We really don't see that changing.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Clark with Piper Jaffray.

MATTHEW TIMOTHY CLARK, PRINCIPAL & SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY COMPANIES, RESEARCH DIVISION: First one just relates to the lending profile. I mean, you talked about what is a very business-friendly market there. But the C&I is only $30 million. Is there -- I guess, why is that, and is there a need to maybe reinvest on that side and hire some folks to help build that portfolio?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Sure. Well we've got Barry Johnston on the phone, and Barry spent, as part of our due diligence process, quite a bit of time going through their entire portfolio. So I'm going to ask Barry to answer that.

BARRY L. JOHNSTON, SENIOR VP & CHIEF CREDIT OFFICER, GLACIER BANCORP, INC.: Yes, yes. What their portfolio, as noted in the numbers, is predominantly commercial real estate, and that's the reason that they are -- one of the reasons that they are really efficient. Once they generate those loan totals, there's a little cost, little maintenance to continue those relationships. Most of them are based on fairly long 20-year amortizations with appropriate 5-year adjustments. So as they build that portfolio over the years, the profitability of that portfolio continues to run, along with the fact that we have -- their pricing compared to our legacy banks is pretty good. So the market there -- historically, there hasn't been a lot of C&I opportunities, not until recently. But with this merger, I feel that there are opportunities to expand that portfolio. And if it takes additional resources to do that, which I anticipate it will, given that the current portfolio sizes per lender, as Randy mentioned, are above average when compared to the rest of our legacy portfolio. So I believe there's an opportunity. We also -- they have been limited somewhat in that area due to their balance sheet. And when we bring our balance sheet to that, the opportunities will increase for those larger transactions that we can facilitate.

MATTHEW TIMOTHY CLARK: Okay. Great. And then what's the expense base that you're using to calculate the 14% cost saves off of? Is that the fourth quarter run rate annualized or is it the last 12 months? Just want to make sure we had a clean number.

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Yes. The 14%, I believe, we took that on the 12-month.

MATTHEW TIMOTHY CLARK: Okay. And then with this deal, looks like you'll be adding 2 new affiliates within the next 6 to 9 months. I guess, what's your -- what's the latest and greatest in terms of your comfort level with being able to manage the number of affiliates? Any plans to change the way the affiliate structure is managed or not?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: No. Very, very comfortable that this will fit in, very self-sufficient, extremely well run. Don't really see it adding a lot of management overhead in terms of -- it'll fit right into our model. In terms of 2 transactions, we've been very, very thoughtful about making sure that we pace these in a way that, we think, that we're very comfortable. So for example, First National Bank of Layton, hopefully, we'll close at the end of April. We will do a conversion in October. We're not planning to do this conversion for Heritage until first quarter -- at the end of the first quarter 2020. So we've spaced these out. We feel good about it, and we feel our team has been through it and is comfortable that this is -- that these are 2 transactions that could be done very well.

MATTHEW TIMOTHY CLARK: Okay, and then just last one from me. Maybe an update on -- to the M&A pipeline in terms of regions or states and size. I think, in the past or at least the last acquisition you talked about, you're seeing deals under $1.5 billion, and that some of the things in the pipeline were a little bit larger, probably this one included.

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Yes, Matthew. There's a lot of deal flow out there. I think on the last call, I said $600 million to kind of at the upper end $1.5 billion. That still seems to be what we're seeing. We do like real good what we feel comfortable bets. In that, this as well as the other deals we've done, very manageable, low execution risk and very accretive to us. So we like that kind of deal in our wheelhouse. So we get a lot of -- we do have -- continue to have a lot of inflow, a lot of inquiries. I think we'll continue to evaluate those. As you guys know, we stick to our very disciplined approach. We say no a lot more than we say yes. This one's been on our road map for a while, so we're very happy to be able to place it there. But wouldn't expect to see really anything else now until -- anything incremental new until 2020. Possible something might come along a little earlier, but, I think, we're thinking this is a good place to be early on in 2019. And we'll continue to look at stuff, but probably won't see anything new until 2020.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) We do have a follow-up question from the line of Michael Young with SunTrust.

MICHAEL MASTERS YOUNG: Just wanted to ask. I know you guys have typically done 2 deals a year. But with CECL and accounting changes coming up in 2020, does that make you more interested in maybe closing a deal prior to year-end or does it not really kind of affect the outlook from your perspective?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Really doesn't affect the outlook. Both these deals will close, hopefully, this year, 2019. So we have First National Bank of Layton, which looks very good, to close at the end of April. Heritage is scheduled to close at the end of July. And so, no, we feel very good about those. But the whole CECL implementation really, we're obviously working on that. But that -- we don't really see that as a driver in terms of our M&A pace.

MICHAEL MASTERS YOUNG: Okay. And then one last one just on the price and being slightly dilutive to tangible book value obviously with a very quicker earnback. But do you think that now with some of the more larger deals you're looking at, that will be a more consistent trend? Or is that more just the nature of how profitable this bank was?

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Yes. No, we're very happy with the very quick earnback. As you know, we operate kind of in a -- at the outer end three-year. So this comes in -- really depends on the transaction. I'd like to see the accretion, the payback over a shorter period of time, but really depends on the total transaction.

OPERATOR: Thank you. This does conclude today's question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Randy Chesler for any further remarks.

RANDALL M. CHESLER: Great. Well thank you, Sarah. No further remarks. Appreciate everybody making time out of their day to the dial in and hear about our latest transaction. As always, we're available, myself, Ron, Don. If you have any questions, just give us a ring. Be happy to follow-up with you. Thank you, and have a great day.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This does conclude today's program. You may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.

September 22, 2009

NEWS PROGRAM

GLENN HUTCHINS, CO-CEO OF SILVER LAKE PARTNERS,

ERIK SCHATZKER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

GLENN HUTCHINS, CO-CEO, SILVER LAKE PARTNERS

ERIK SCHATZKER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

GLENN HUTCHINS, CO-CEO, SILVER LAKE PARTNERS

(Source: Bloomberg)

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

14:12

ERIK SCHATZKER, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We are here with Glenn Hutchins. Glenn, we have to start off with Skype. It's in the headlines. It's obviously the subject of some litigation. I wouldn't be surprised if you are a little bit constrained on what you can say, but I do want to ask you this. The founders of Skype have taken what some people might call a scorched earth tactic with regard to litigation. Has this caught you off guard? Are you surprised?

GLENN HUTCHINS, CO-CEO, SILVER LAKE PARTNERS: No comment.

SCHATZKER: Okay, just so our viewers are clear that is basically where we're going to go on the subject of Skype because I don't want to waste their time. I certainly don't want to waste yours. Okay, let's move on then.

Let's talk about finance. The G-20 taking place this week in Pittsburgh. You have written passionately about how we need to look at the credit crisis, how it developed, and where we need to go from here. A lot of focus at the G-20 on bonuses. You're not a banker, but you do business with these people. You were in the Clinton Administration, you understand the kinds of pressures that policy makers are under. Are they taking the right approach?

HUTCHINS: By the way, do I get a break on my terminal service - price break on my terminal service for being here today?

SCHATZKER: We'll have to talk with the Chair -

(CROSSTALK)

HUTCHINS: I think what we need to do is restore confidence in the financial markets. Obviously the bonus issue is one that has created a bunch of political agita. I think the background of that is that we are in a time period in which American incomes have stagnated. A lot of people have suffered.

Unemployment is going up substantially. America is in a transition in important parts of our manufacturing base are in decline. And to see people making this much money, even though it might have been earned or might have been justified in some uneconomic sense, it's a political problem and it creates a lack of confidence. It contributes to a lack of confidence in the markets. So I think in general what we can do - again, this doesn't relate to me, it doesn't relate to my firm, except that we as participants in the broader economy, I think what we can do to restore confidence with appropriate regulation of compensation as part of that is the appropriate thing to do.

SCHATZKER: When we think about regulating financial services, are there any guiding principles you think we need to follow?

HUTCHINS: Yes, I think in general there are two key rationales for regulation. One is systemic risk. Does the firm generate, or its activities generate systemic risk? Do we need to regulate it to protect the system?

And second, is there consumer protection element? And because we do need to protect consumers and make sure again people can have trust in the marketplace to do business with folks. And I think we learned some from the mortgage economy that a whole bunch of people got products that were inappropriate for them, whether they were knowledgeable about it or not. We don't know. And so, to protect consumers from those sort of problems and create consumer confidence in the financial system again, I think, is very important.

SCHATZKER: Consumer protection and systemic risk. Okay, as you point out, you're not effectively part of Wall Street. Why was it important to you to go back and understand this debate?

HUTCHINS: Well I am an investor. Two things - one is that I, as an investor - I think you need to have to a very thorough understanding of the macro economic environment as a backdrop to what your investments are, what your investments can be. And also, I think that if you have a perspective that is useful to public debate, you have some degree of an obligation to share it with others.

SCHATZKER: Okay, let's talk about private equity. It did seem back in 2007 like it was the golden age. Doesn't feel like the golden age anymore. There is a lack of leverage that affects some firms perhaps more than yours, but there is also a premium being placed on liquidity, as Larry Fink of Blackrock reminded us the other day. People shouldn't be under the misunderstanding perhaps that private equity is a liquid investment, but could it be caught up in the collateral damage as endowments of other institutions think carefully about how much money they are willing to dedicate to illiquid instruments?

HUTCHINS: Well I think the biggest issue with respect to liquidity on behalf of the institutions that invest in alternative assets, which takes in private equity, hedge funds, venture capital, et cetera, relates to hedge funds for two reasons. One is they were bought to -- expected to own liquid instruments which were rendered illiquid by the liquidity crisis.

And second, they were thought to have - expected by their investors to have periodic liquidity and many of them put up what are called gates and restricted people's access to their securities. So I think that issue, the liquidity problem that we've all faced relates more to the hedge fund business model than to the private equity business model that was well understood to be an illiquid asset class.

That's point one. Point two is as the resources in certain pools of capital shrink, there might well be smaller-sized funds in the future. There might well be less robust fundraising. But on the other hand that is being offset by large pools of new capital in other geographies of the world entering the alternative asset market.

(CROSSTALK)

SCHATZKER: China, Singapore, that kind of thing?

HUTCHINS: Yes, exactly right.

SCHATZKER: Okay, with about 30 seconds to go, you focus on tech. We just saw a big tech deal today - Dell buying Pro Systems (ph), yesterday in fact. How is that going to affect your business? You've got a lot of big tech interests? You're competing for some of the same companies.

HUTCHINS: Look, I want to first congratulate the guys at Dell for that transaction.. I thought it was a terrific idea what they did and they are on the right track combining services with their hardware offering. And it is consistent with a broad theme that we have had of the consolidation generally in the technology industry and the consolidation specifically in the services sector. So it is very consistent with our investment model. There are plenty of companies out there for us to invest in. We're not competing with Michael Dell for any businesses.

SCHATZKER: All right, Glenn. Thank you very much. Glenn Hutchins, Co-CEO of Silver lake Partners.

HUTCHINS: So do I get that price break?

SCHATZKER: We'll be talking about it.

urn:contentItem:60YN-R151-DYDY-900S-00000-00Gli Usa sono una società spaccata;Che va alle elezioni con l'intento, non di battere, ma di annientare l'avversario politico2020-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:13ZLexisNexisPRIMO PIANOPag. 11Gli Usa sono una società spaccataChe va alle elezioni con l'intento, non di battere, ma di annientare l'avversario politicoFederico Ferraù Il Sussidiario.net

I dem alzano i toni per indurre i giovani a votare

La democrazia americana rischia, ma i mercati fanno, imperturbabili, il loro dovere: moltiplicare i profitti. Dunque non è Wall Street ad avvertirci di quello che sta per accadere. «Le borse reggono qualsiasi urto se il potere garantisce denaro gratis, spesa pubblica a volontà per mantenere i consumi, tasse basse per la Silicon Valley e deregulation per Wall Street» dice Chris Foster, una vita nei mercati finanziari tra Londra e New York. Il fatto è che «nessuno dei due lati accetterà la sconfitta», spiega Foster, e grandi fiumi di denaro sono e saranno investiti per produrre instabilità. La battaglia per la Corte suprema, con la nomina di Amy Coney Barrett, si colloca in questo contesto. I democratici useranno il debate per portare alle urne la componente più di sinistra dei Dems, che, delusa dalla scarsa leadership di Biden, non andrebbe a votare.

E questo sarà solo l'inizio. Insomma, scordiamoci il pareggio Bush-Gore, perché la situazione è realmente preoccupante.Domanda. Foster, le elezioni americane sono o no in cima alle preoccupazioni degli investitori?Risposta. La tensione sta salendo, ma se guardiamo alla tenuta dell'azionario americano in combinazione con il grande rally dei titoli obbligazionari (dai titoli del governo Usa alle obbligazioni corporate ad alto rischio) diremmo che da fine marzo a oggi il mercato guarda più alle aspettative sui risultati aziendali e al supporto fiscale e monetario che al gioco delle probabilità Trump-Biden.D. Quindi lei sostiene che mentre il mondo trepida per i risultati del 3 novembre, Wall Street pensa alle trimestrali in arrivo tra ottobre e novembre? R. Ci sono centinaia di papers accademici e analisi dei brokers che cercano di identificare delle correlazioni significative tra risultati Democrats vs Republicans e mercato azionario, tra anni elettorali e forza del dollaro, eccetera. Nessun risultato è convincente.D. Davvero non ci sono punti di riferimento?R. L'ho detto: solo il trend dei corporate earnings e le stime di crescita degli earnings per i trimestri successivi sembrano identificare l'unico «pattern» credibile. I tassi a zero aiutano a sostenere valutazioni altissime e altrimenti considerabili folli.D. Ma perché accennava all'aumento della tensione negli investitori? R. Queste elezioni sono profondamente diverse dalle precedenti. Da qui nasce la tensione, che non si traduce ancora in un calo di mercato per il semplice motivo che l'outlook economico è fortemente influenzato dalle previsioni di politica fiscale senza vincoli di bilancio e supportata da una politica monetaria che a grandi passi va verso un concetto vicino alla Modern Monetary Theory (Mmt).D. Non ci ha detto il vero fattore di differenza tra queste elezioni e le altre.R. Il livello di polarizzazione della politica Usa ha raggiunto livelli inimmaginabili fino pochi anni fa. E non era pensabile che una democrazia storicamente bipolare e matura come quella americana potesse essere oggi davvero in una situazione tale da non saper gestire un aumento di tale polarizzazione, con rischi forse più conosciuti nelle democrazie europee che in Usa.D. Cioè, in parole povere, come in molti sostengono, Trump è oggi più che mai una minaccia per il sistema democratico Usa?R. Lo stile e la gestione del potere combinati con la retorica di Trump sono nuovi nel contesto Usa. Ma sarebbe estremamente superficiale e tristemente mainstream individuare nel «fattore Trump» il rischio principale per la democrazia americana.D. Si spieghi, perché gli opinionisti di tutto il mondo temono che Trump non accetti un passaggio di potere in modo indolore…R. Non immagino proprio un Trump chiuso in un bunker con Melania a dare istruzioni all'esercito nel caso ci sia una chiara sconfitta, per capirci.D. E allora chi è una minaccia alla democrazia?R. Diversi fattori che sono esplosi tutti insieme negli ultimi 10 anni hanno generato situazioni anomale e uniche nel panorama Usa.D. Andiamo con ordine.R. Innanzitutto, non dimentichiamo che il fenomeno Trump dovrebbe recare un'etichetta sul retro: made in Obama-Clinton. Cioè, le catastrofiche politiche sociali ed economiche della precedente amministrazione, vale a dire la più grande accelerazione delle disparità sociali negli annali Usa, la perdita di controllo del fattore Cina, in combinazione con un approccio dogmatico alla globalizzazione come generatore di benessere globale, hanno alimentato varie forme di estremismo sia a destra che a sinistra. Proporzionalmente, il partito democratico si è spinto più a sinistra di quanto i repubblicani siano scivolati verso destra.D. E poi?R. E poi due fenomeni prevedibili ma poco contestualizzati: l'aumento smodato del potere della Silicon Valley come grande filtro della «verità accettabile» e la crescita della componente di sinistra nei Dems. Ricorda le elezioni del 2000, Bush contro Al Gore?D. Sì certo, ci sono somiglianze?R. No. L'opposto. L'esito era stato davvero eccezionale per incertezza, ma al di là dello sgomento e dell'incredulità dei media europei che avevano pre-celebrato la vittoria del profeta green, Al Gore, il risultato era stato accettato senza appello alla violenza. In Europa avremmo avuto manifestazioni molto violente.D. E oggi?R. Oggi nessuno dei due lati accetterà la sconfitta, e fattore chiave, il partito democratico di oggi non è quello moderato di allora. E nemmeno quello repubblicano.D. La nomina di Amy Coney Barrett, probabilmente confermata tra 10 giorni in Senato, come aumenterà la tensione?R. La giudice Ginsburg, senza volerlo, morendo ha fatto un grande favore ai democratici.D. Ma cosa dice, Foster?R. Mai credere ai sondaggi americani: i democratici erano diretti verso una probabile sconfitta, soprattutto a causa dei giovani. I giovani Usa sono in maggioranza pro Dems, soprattutto quelli che frequentano i colleges, ma non amano andare a votare senza una motivazione che in Europa chiameremmo ideologico-movimentista.La spirale di emozioni e anche di violenza verbale del dibattito sulla Supreme Court non potrà che avere un effetto positivo sulla partecipazione dei giovani al voto.D. Può spiegarsi meglio?R. La componente giovane del partito democratico è fondamentalmente di sinistra e aveva aspettative di una virata a sinistra della leadership del partito. Biden rappresenta lo status quo e l'opportunismo del politico di professione senza carisma; si pensi a quanto, al contrario, Bernie Sanders ha acceso le speranze dei giovani e degli esclusi.D. E Kamala Harris?R. È stata imposta dai grandi del tech (quindi i soliti volti senza scrupoli della Silicon Valley) e quindi nemmeno lei è il vero volto nuovo della società americana: la Harris rappresenta il prezzo che i democratici hanno dovuto pagare per mantenere tutto il blocco dei colossi tech, inclusi Facebook, Alphabet, Twitter dal proprio lato.D. Un esempio qualsiasi dell'aria che si respira… il primo che le viene. R. Il figlio di un mio amico iscritto alla Columbia sostiene che dei suoi classmates, tutti anti-Trump, quasi nessuno voterà Biden. Semplicemente non andrà a votare perché disgustato da un'altra tornata elettorale che spegnerà ogni speranza per una società su misura per loro.D. E la nomina della signora Barrett alla Corte suprema porterà davvero i giovani alle urne a votare Biden?R. Questo è l'obiettivo del caos che sta per scatenarsi negli Usa: aizzare gli animi della componente più a sinistra dei dems che non andrebbe a votare. Le elezioni si vincono o si perdono sull'economia, si dice, ma sono i temi ideologici che spingono i giovani ad andare alle urne e a fare la differenza. Le minorities sono già molto politicizzate e non tradiranno il lato dem. Chi potrebbe tradire è chi si sente a sua volta tradito per la seconda volta dall'eliminazione «scientifica» di Bernie Sanders.D. Ma quando lei parla di caos, esattamente che cosa intende?R. Intendo manifestazioni di piazza peggiori di quelle che abbiamo visto nei mesi scorsi come reazione all'uccisione di George Floyd. Inoltre, esistono fonti di finanziamento e supporto politico ma anche mediatico ben più interessate a mantenere il caos per lungo tempo. Il tema Black Lives Matter, per esempio, non interessa a nessuno di quelli che ne fanno uso quotidiano per marketing. Qui invece si gioca una parte importante della storia Usa e troppi interessi sono direttamente coinvolti.D. E tutto questo non avrebbe ripercussioni su Wall Street?R. Le borse reggono qualsiasi urto se il potere garantisce denaro gratis, spesa pubblica a volontà per mantenere un minimo di crescita dei consumi, tasse basse per la Silicon Valley e deregulation per Wall Street. Biden può creare un po' di volatilità a causa del tema corporate tax e regulation, ma alla fine i big tech e Wall Street non lo stanno finanziando per amicizia. Joe può essere poco brillante ma è sicuramente affidabile, niente sorprese.
